    30        <name>/rig/         Human workspaces
    31     polecats/               Polecat settings parent (shared)
    32         .claude/settings.json  (context via gt prime)
    33         <name>/rig/         Worker worktrees
    34```
    35
    36**Key points:**
    37
    38- Rig root is a container, not a clone
    39- `.repo.git/` is bare - refinery and polecats are worktrees
    40- Per-rig `mayor/rig/` holds canonical `.beads/`, others inherit via redirect
    41- Settings placed in parent dirs (not git clones) for upward traversal
    42
    43## Beads Routing
    44
    45Gas Town routes beads commands based on issue ID prefix. You don't need to think
    46about which database to use - just use the issue ID.
    47
    48```bash
    49bd show gp-xyz    # Routes to greenplace rig's beads
    50bd show hq-abc    # Routes to town-level beads
    51bd show wyv-123   # Routes to wyvern rig's beads
    52```
    53
    54**How it works**: Routes are defined in `~/gt/.beads/routes.jsonl`. Each rig's
    55prefix maps to its beads location (the mayor's clone in that rig).
    56
    57| Prefix | Routes To | Purpose |
    58|--------|-----------|---------|
    59| `hq-*` | `~/gt/.beads/` | Mayor mail, cross-rig coordination |
    60| `gp-*` | `~/gt/greenplace/mayor/rig/.beads/` | Greenplace project issues |
    61| `wyv-*` | `~/gt/wyvern/mayor/rig/.beads/` | Wyvern project issues |
    62
    63Debug routing: `BD_DEBUG_ROUTING=1 bd show <id>`
    64
    65## Configuration
    66
    67### Rig Config (`config.json`)
    68
    69```json
    70{
    71  "type": "rig",
    72  "name": "myproject",
    73  "git_url": "https://github.com/...",
    74  "beads": { "prefix": "mp" }
    75}
    76```
    77
    78### Settings (`settings/config.json`)
    79
    80```json
    81{
    82  "theme": "desert",
    83  "max_workers": 5,
    84  "merge_queue": { "enabled": true }
    85}
    86```
    87
    88### Runtime (`.runtime/` - gitignored)
    89
    90Process state, PIDs, ephemeral data.
    91
    92## Formula Format
    93
    94```toml
    95formula = "name"
    96type = "workflow"           # workflow | expansion | aspect
    97version = 1
    98description = "..."
    99
   100[vars.feature]
   101description = "..."
   102required = true
   103
   104[[steps]]
   105id = "step-id"
   106title = "{{feature}}"
   107description = "..."
   108needs = ["other-step"]      # Dependencies
   109```
   110
   111**Composition:**
   112
   113```toml
   114extends = ["base-formula"]
   115
   116[compose]
   117aspects = ["cross-cutting"]
   118
   119[[compose.expand]]
   120target = "step-id"
   121with = "macro-formula"
   122```
   123
   124## Molecule Lifecycle
   125
   126```
   127Formula (source TOML)  "Ice-9"
   128    
   129     bd cook
   130Protomolecule (frozen template)  Solid
   131    
   132     bd mol pour  Mol (persistent)  Liquid  bd squash  Digest
   133    
   134     bd mol wisp  Wisp (ephemeral)  Vapor  bd squash  Digest
   135                                                   bd burn  (gone)
   136```
   137
   138**Note**: Wisps are stored in `.beads/` with an ephemeral flag - they're not
   139persisted to JSONL. They exist only in memory during execution.
   140
   141## Molecule Commands
   142
   143**Principle**: `bd` = beads data operations, `gt` = agent operations.
   144
   145### Beads Operations (bd)
   146
   147```bash
   148# Formulas
   149bd formula list              # Available formulas
   150bd formula show <name>       # Formula details
   151bd cook <formula>            # Formula  Proto
   152
   153# Molecules (data operations)
   154bd mol list                  # Available protos
   155bd mol show <id>             # Proto details
   156bd mol pour <proto>          # Create mol
   157bd mol wisp <proto>          # Create wisp
   158bd mol bond <proto> <parent> # Attach to existing mol
   159bd mol squash <id>           # Condense to digest (explicit ID)
   160bd mol burn <id>             # Discard wisp (explicit ID)
   161```
   162
   163### Agent Operations (gt)
   164
   165```bash
   166# Hook management (operates on current agent's hook)
   167gt hook                    # What's on MY hook
   168gt mol current               # What should I work on next
   169gt mol progress <id>         # Execution progress of molecule
   170gt mol attach <bead> <mol>   # Pin molecule to bead
   171gt mol detach <bead>         # Unpin molecule from bead
   172gt mol attach-from-mail <id> # Attach from mail message
   173
   174# Agent lifecycle (operates on agent's attached molecule)
   175gt mol burn                  # Burn attached molecule (no ID needed)
   176gt mol squash                # Squash attached molecule (no ID needed)
   177gt mol step done <step>      # Complete a molecule step
   178```
   179
   180**Key distinction**: `bd mol burn/squash <id>` take explicit molecule IDs.
   181`gt mol burn/squash` operate on the current agent's attached molecule
   182(auto-detected from working directory).
   183
   184## Agent Lifecycle
   185
   186### Polecat Shutdown
   187
   188```
   1891. Complete work steps
   1902. bd mol squash (create digest)
   1913. Submit to merge queue
   1924. gt handoff (request shutdown)
   1935. Wait for Witness to kill session
   1946. Witness removes worktree + branch
   195```
   196
   197### Session Cycling
   198
   199```
   2001. Agent notices context filling
   2012. gt handoff (sends mail to self)
   2023. Manager kills session
   2034. Manager starts new session
   2045. New session reads handoff mail
   205```
   206
   207## Environment Variables
   208
   209Gas Town sets environment variables for each agent session via `config.AgentEnv()`.
   210These are set in tmux session environment when agents are spawned.
   211
   212### Core Variables (All Agents)
   213
   214| Variable | Purpose | Example |
   215|----------|---------|---------|
   216| `GT_ROLE` | Agent role type | `mayor`, `witness`, `polecat`, `crew` |
   217| `GT_ROOT` | Town root directory | `/home/user/gt` |
   218| `BD_ACTOR` | Agent identity for attribution | `gastown/polecats/toast` |
   219| `GIT_AUTHOR_NAME` | Commit attribution (same as BD_ACTOR) | `gastown/polecats/toast` |
   220| `BEADS_DIR` | Beads database location | `/home/user/gt/gastown/.beads` |
   221
   222### Rig-Level Variables
   223
   224| Variable | Purpose | Roles |
   225|----------|---------|-------|
   226| `GT_RIG` | Rig name | witness, refinery, polecat, crew |
   227| `GT_POLECAT` | Polecat worker name | polecat only |
   228| `GT_CREW` | Crew worker name | crew only |
   229| `BEADS_AGENT_NAME` | Agent name for beads operations | polecat, crew |
   230| `BEADS_NO_DAEMON` | Disable beads daemon (isolated context) | polecat, crew |
   231
   232### Other Variables
   233
   234| Variable | Purpose |
   235|----------|---------|
   236| `GIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL` | Workspace owner email (from git config) |
   237| `GT_TOWN_ROOT` | Override town root detection (manual use) |
   238| `CLAUDE_RUNTIME_CONFIG_DIR` | Custom Claude settings directory |
   239
   240### Environment by Role
   241
   242| Role | Key Variables |
   243|------|---------------|
   244| **Mayor** | `GT_ROLE=mayor`, `BD_ACTOR=mayor` |
   245| **Deacon** | `GT_ROLE=deacon`, `BD_ACTOR=deacon` |
   246| **Boot** | `GT_ROLE=boot`, `BD_ACTOR=deacon-boot` |
   247| **Witness** | `GT_ROLE=witness`, `GT_RIG=<rig>`, `BD_ACTOR=<rig>/witness` |
   248| **Refinery** | `GT_ROLE=refinery`, `GT_RIG=<rig>`, `BD_ACTOR=<rig>/refinery` |
   249| **Polecat** | `GT_ROLE=polecat`, `GT_RIG=<rig>`, `GT_POLECAT=<name>`, `BD_ACTOR=<rig>/polecats/<name>` |
   250| **Crew** | `GT_ROLE=crew`, `GT_RIG=<rig>`, `GT_CREW=<name>`, `BD_ACTOR=<rig>/crew/<name>` |
   251
   252### Doctor Check
   253
   254The `gt doctor` command verifies that running tmux sessions have correct
   255environment variables. Mismatches are reported as warnings:
   256
   257```
   258 env-vars: Found 3 env var mismatch(es) across 1 session(s)
   259    hq-mayor: missing GT_ROOT (expected "/home/user/gt")
   260```
   261
   262Fix by restarting sessions: `gt shutdown && gt up`
   263
   264## Agent Working Directories and Settings
   265
   266Each agent runs in a specific working directory and has its own Claude settings.
   267Understanding this hierarchy is essential for proper configuration.
   268
   269### Working Directories by Role
   270
   271| Role | Working Directory | Notes |
   272|------|-------------------|-------|
   273| **Mayor** | `~/gt/mayor/` | Town-level coordinator, isolated from rigs |
   274| **Deacon** | `~/gt/deacon/` | Background supervisor daemon |
   275| **Witness** | `~/gt/<rig>/witness/` | No git clone, monitors polecats only |
   276| **Refinery** | `~/gt/<rig>/refinery/rig/` | Worktree on main branch |
   277| **Crew** | `~/gt/<rig>/crew/<name>/rig/` | Persistent human workspace clone |
   278| **Polecat** | `~/gt/<rig>/polecats/<name>/rig/` | Ephemeral worker worktree |
   279
   280Note: The per-rig `<rig>/mayor/rig/` directory is NOT a working directoryit's
   281a git clone that holds the canonical `.beads/` database for that rig.
   282
   283### Settings File Locations
   284
   285Claude Code searches for `.claude/settings.json` starting from the working
   286directory and traversing upward. Settings are placed in **parent directories**
   287(not inside git clones) so they're found via directory traversal without
   288polluting source repositories:
   289
   290```
   291~/gt/
   292 mayor/.claude/settings.json          # Mayor settings
   293 deacon/.claude/settings.json         # Deacon settings
   294 <rig>/
   295     witness/.claude/settings.json    # Witness settings (no rig/ subdir)
   296     refinery/.claude/settings.json   # Found by refinery/rig/ via traversal
   297     crew/.claude/settings.json       # Shared by all crew/<name>/rig/
   298     polecats/.claude/settings.json   # Shared by all polecats/<name>/rig/
   299```
   300
   301**Why parent directories?** Agents working in git clones (like `refinery/rig/`)
   302would pollute the source repo if settings were placed there. By putting settings
   303one level up, Claude finds them via upward traversal, and all workers of the
   304same type share the same settings.
   305
   306### CLAUDE.md Locations
   307
   308Role context is delivered via CLAUDE.md files or ephemeral injection:
   309
   310| Role | CLAUDE.md Location | Method |
   311|------|-------------------|--------|
   312| **Mayor** | `~/gt/mayor/CLAUDE.md` | On disk |
   313| **Deacon** | (none) | Injected via `gt prime` at SessionStart |
   314| **Witness** | (none) | Injected via `gt prime` at SessionStart |
   315| **Refinery** | `<rig>/refinery/rig/CLAUDE.md` | On disk (inside worktree) |
   316| **Crew** | (none) | Injected via `gt prime` at SessionStart |
   317| **Polecat** | (none) | Injected via `gt prime` at SessionStart |
   318
   319Additionally, each rig has `<rig>/mayor/rig/CLAUDE.md` for the per-rig mayor clone
   320(used for beads operations, not a running agent).
   321
   322**Why ephemeral injection?** Writing CLAUDE.md into git clones would:
   3231. Pollute source repos when agents commit/push
   3242. Leak Gas Town internals into project history
   3253. Conflict with project-specific CLAUDE.md files
   326
   327The `gt prime` command runs at SessionStart hook and injects context without
   328persisting it to disk.
   329
   330### Sparse Checkout (Source Repo Isolation)
   331
   332When agents work on source repositories that have their own Claude Code configuration,
   333Gas Town uses git sparse checkout to exclude all context files:
   334
   335```bash
   336# Automatically configured for worktrees - excludes:
   337# - .claude/       : settings, rules, agents, commands
   338# - CLAUDE.md      : primary context file
   339# - CLAUDE.local.md: personal context file
   340# - .mcp.json      : MCP server configuration
   341git sparse-checkout set --no-cone '/*' '!/.claude/' '!/CLAUDE.md' '!/CLAUDE.local.md' '!/.mcp.json'
   342```
   343
   344This ensures agents use Gas Town's context, not the source repo's instructions.
   345
   346**Doctor check**: `gt doctor` verifies sparse checkout is configured correctly.
   347Run `gt doctor --fix` to update legacy configurations missing the newer patterns.
   348
   349### Settings Inheritance
   350
   351Claude Code's settings search order (first match wins):
   352
   3531. `.claude/settings.json` in current working directory
   3542. `.claude/settings.json` in parent directories (traversing up)
   3553. `~/.claude/settings.json` (user global settings)
   356
   357Gas Town places settings at each agent's working directory root, so agents
   358find their role-specific settings before reaching any parent or global config.
   359
   360### Settings Templates
   361
   362Gas Town uses two settings templates based on role type:
   363
   364| Type | Roles | Key Difference |
   365|------|-------|----------------|
   366| **Interactive** | Mayor, Crew | Mail injected on `UserPromptSubmit` hook |
   367| **Autonomous** | Polecat, Witness, Refinery, Deacon | Mail injected on `SessionStart` hook |
   368
   369Autonomous agents may start without user input, so they need mail checked
   370at session start. Interactive agents wait for user prompts.
   371
   372### Troubleshooting
   373
   374| Problem | Solution |
   375|---------|----------|
   376| Agent using wrong settings | Check `gt doctor`, verify sparse checkout |
   377| Settings not found | Ensure `.claude/settings.json` exists at role home |
   378| Source repo settings leaking | Run `gt doctor --fix` to configure sparse checkout |
   379| Mayor settings affecting polecats | Mayor should run in `mayor/`, not town root |
   380
   381## CLI Reference
   382
   383### Town Management
   384
   385```bash
   386gt install [path]            # Create town
   387gt install --git             # With git init
   388gt doctor                    # Health check
   389gt doctor --fix              # Auto-repair
   390```
   391
   392### Configuration
   393
   394```bash
   395# Agent management
   396gt config agent list [--json]     # List all agents (built-in + custom)
   397gt config agent get <name>        # Show agent configuration
   398gt config agent set <name> <cmd>  # Create or update custom agent
   399gt config agent remove <name>     # Remove custom agent (built-ins protected)
   400
   401# Default agent
   402gt config default-agent [name]    # Get or set town default agent
   403```
   404
   405**Built-in agents**: `claude`, `gemini`, `codex`, `cursor`, `auggie`, `amp`
   406
   407**Custom agents**: Define per-town via CLI or JSON:
   408```bash
   409gt config agent set claude-glm "claude-glm --model glm-4"
   410gt config agent set claude "claude-opus"  # Override built-in
   411gt config default-agent claude-glm       # Set default
   412```
   413
   414**Advanced agent config** (`settings/agents.json`):
   415```json
   416{
   417  "version": 1,
   418  "agents": {
   419    "opencode": {
   420      "command": "opencode",
   421      "args": [],
   422      "resume_flag": "--session",
   423      "resume_style": "flag",
   424      "non_interactive": {
   425        "subcommand": "run",
   426        "output_flag": "--format json"
   427      }
   428    }
   429  }
   430}
   431```
   432
   433**Rig-level agents** (`<rig>/settings/config.json`):
   434```json
   435{
   436  "type": "rig-settings",
   437  "version": 1,
   438  "agent": "opencode",
   439  "agents": {
   440    "opencode": {
   441      "command": "opencode",
   442      "args": ["--session"]
   443    }
   444  }
   445}
   446```
   447
   448**Agent resolution order**: rig-level  town-level  built-in presets.
   449
   450For OpenCode autonomous mode, set env var in your shell profile:
   451```bash
   452export OPENCODE_PERMISSION='{"*":"allow"}'
   453```
   454
   455### Rig Management
   456
   457```bash
   458gt rig add <name> <url>
   459gt rig list
   460gt rig remove <name>
   461```
   462
   463### Convoy Management (Primary Dashboard)
   464
   465```bash
   466gt convoy list                          # Dashboard of active convoys
   467gt convoy status [convoy-id]            # Show progress ( hq-cv-*)
   468gt convoy create "name" [issues...]     # Create convoy tracking issues
   469gt convoy create "name" gt-a bd-b --notify mayor/  # With notification
   470gt convoy list --all                    # Include landed convoys
   471gt convoy list --status=closed          # Only landed convoys
   472```
   473
   474Note: "Swarm" is ephemeral (workers on a convoy's issues). See [Convoys](concepts/convoy.md).
   475
   476### Work Assignment
   477
   478```bash
   479# Standard workflow: convoy first, then sling
   480gt convoy create "Feature X" gt-abc gt-def
   481gt sling gt-abc <rig>                    # Assign to polecat
   482gt sling gt-abc <rig> --agent codex      # Override runtime for this sling/spawn
   483gt sling <proto> --on gt-def <rig>       # With workflow template
   484
   485# Quick sling (auto-creates convoy)
   486gt sling <bead> <rig>                    # Auto-convoy for dashboard visibility
   487```
   488
   489Agent overrides:
   490
   491- `gt start --agent <alias>` overrides the Mayor/Deacon runtime for this launch.
   492- `gt mayor start|attach|restart --agent <alias>` and `gt deacon start|attach|restart --agent <alias>` do the same.
   493- `gt start crew <name> --agent <alias>` and `gt crew at <name> --agent <alias>` override the crew worker runtime.
   494
   495### Communication
   496
   497```bash
   498gt mail inbox
   499gt mail read <id>
   500gt mail send <addr> -s "Subject" -m "Body"
   501gt mail send --human -s "..."    # To overseer
   502```
   503
   504### Escalation
   505
   506```bash
   507gt escalate "topic"              # Default: MEDIUM severity
   508gt escalate -s CRITICAL "msg"    # Urgent, immediate attention
   509gt escalate -s HIGH "msg"        # Important blocker
   510gt escalate -s MEDIUM "msg" -m "Details..."
   511```
   512
   513See [escalation.md](design/escalation.md) for full protocol.
   514
   515### Sessions
   516
   517```bash
   518gt handoff                   # Request cycle (context-aware)
   519gt handoff --shutdown        # Terminate (polecats)
   520gt session stop <rig>/<agent>
   521gt peek <agent>              # Check health
   522gt nudge <agent> "message"   # Send message to agent
   523gt seance                    # List discoverable predecessor sessions
   524gt seance --talk <id>        # Talk to predecessor (full context)
   525gt seance --talk <id> -p "Where is X?"  # One-shot question
   526```
   527
   528**Session Discovery**: Each session has a startup nudge that becomes searchable
   529in Claude's `/resume` picker:
   530
   531```
   532[GAS TOWN] recipient <- sender  timestamp  topic[:mol-id]
   533```
   534
   535Example: `[GAS TOWN] gastown/crew/gus <- human  2025-12-30T15:42  restart`
   536
   537**IMPORTANT**: Always use `gt nudge` to send messages to Claude sessions.
   538Never use raw `tmux send-keys` - it doesn't handle Claude's input correctly.
   539`gt nudge` uses literal mode + debounce + separate Enter for reliable delivery.
   540
   541### Emergency
   542
   543```bash
   544gt stop --all                # Kill all sessions
   545gt stop --rig <name>         # Kill rig sessions
   546```
   547
   548## Beads Commands (bd)
   549
   550```bash
   551bd ready                     # Work with no blockers
   552bd list --status=open
   553bd list --status=in_progress
   554bd show <id>
   555bd create --title="..." --type=task
   556bd update <id> --status=in_progress
   557bd close <id>
   558bd dep add <child> <parent>  # child depends on parent
   559bd sync                      # Push/pull changes
   560```
   561
   562## Patrol Agents
   563
   564Deacon, Witness, and Refinery run continuous patrol loops using wisps:
   565
   566| Agent | Patrol Molecule | Responsibility |
   567|-------|-----------------|----------------|
   568| **Deacon** | `mol-deacon-patrol` | Agent lifecycle, plugin execution, health checks |
   569| **Witness** | `mol-witness-patrol` | Monitor polecats, nudge stuck workers |
   570| **Refinery** | `mol-refinery-patrol` | Process merge queue, review MRs |
   571
   572```
   5731. bd mol wisp mol-<role>-patrol
   5742. Execute steps (check workers, process queue, run plugins)
   5753. bd mol squash (or burn if routine)
   5764. Loop
   577```
   578
   579## Plugin Molecules
   580
   581Plugins are molecules with specific labels:
   582
   583```json
   584{
   585  "id": "mol-security-scan",
   586  "labels": ["template", "plugin", "witness", "tier:haiku"]
   587}
   588```
   589
   590Patrol molecules bond plugins dynamically:
   591
   592```bash
   593bd mol bond mol-security-scan $PATROL_ID --var scope="$SCOPE"
   594```
   595
   596## Common Issues
   597
   598| Problem | Solution |
   599|---------|----------|
   600| Agent in wrong directory | Check cwd, `gt doctor` |
   601| Beads prefix mismatch | Check `bd show` vs rig config |
   602| Worktree conflicts | Ensure `BEADS_NO_DAEMON=1` for polecats |
   603| Stuck worker | `gt nudge`, then `gt peek` |
   604| Dirty git state | Commit or discard, then `gt handoff` |
   605
   606## Architecture Notes
   607
   608**Bare repo pattern**: `.repo.git/` is bare (no working dir). Refinery and polecats are worktrees sharing refs. Polecat branches visible to refinery immediately.
   609
   610**Beads as control plane**: No separate orchestrator. Molecule steps ARE beads issues. State transitions are git commits.
   611
   612**Nondeterministic idempotence**: Any worker can continue any molecule. Steps are atomic checkpoints in beads.
   613
   614**Convoy tracking**: Convoys track batched work across rigs. A "swarm" is ephemeral - just the workers currently on a convoy's issues. See [Convoys](concepts/convoy.md) for details.
   615

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

# Gas Town Reference

Technical reference for Gas Town internals. Read the README first.

## Directory Structure

```
~/gt/                           Town root
 .beads/                     Town-level beads (hq-* prefix)
 mayor/                      Mayor agent home (town coordinator)
    town.json               Town configuration
    CLAUDE.md               Mayor context (on disk)
    .claude/settings.json   Mayor Claude settings
 deacon/                     Deacon agent home (background supervisor)
    .claude/settings.json   Deacon settings (context via gt prime)
 <rig>/                      Project container (NOT a git clone)
     config.json             Rig identity
     .beads/  mayor/rig/.beads
     .repo.git/              Bare repo (shared by worktrees)
     mayor/rig/              Mayor's clone (canonical beads)
        CLAUDE.md           Per-rig mayor context (on disk)
     witness/                Witness agent home (monitors only)
        .claude/settings.json  (context via gt prime)
     refinery/               Refinery settings parent
        .claude/settings.json
        rig/                Worktree on main
            CLAUDE.md       Refinery context (on disk)
     crew/                   Crew settings parent (shared)
        .claude/settings.json  (context via gt prime)
        <name>/rig/         Human workspaces
     polecats/               Polecat settings parent (shared)
         .claude/settings.json  (context via gt prime)
         <name>/rig/         Worker worktrees
```

**Key points:**

- Rig root is a container, not a clone
- `.repo.git/` is bare - refinery and polecats are worktrees
- Per-rig `mayor/rig/` holds canonical `.beads/`, others inherit via redirect
- Settings placed in parent dirs (not git clones) for upward traversal

## Beads Routing

Gas Town routes beads commands based on issue ID prefix. You don't need to think
about which database to use - just use the issue ID.

```bash
bd show gp-xyz    # Routes to greenplace rig's beads
bd show hq-abc    # Routes to town-level beads
bd show wyv-123   # Routes to wyvern rig's beads
```

**How it works**: Routes are defined in `~/gt/.beads/routes.jsonl`. Each rig's
prefix maps to its beads location (the mayor's clone in that rig).

| Prefix | Routes To | Purpose |
|--------|-----------|---------|
| `hq-*` | `~/gt/.beads/` | Mayor mail, cross-rig coordination |
| `gp-*` | `~/gt/greenplace/mayor/rig/.beads/` | Greenplace project issues |
| `wyv-*` | `~/gt/wyvern/mayor/rig/.beads/` | Wyvern project issues |

Debug routing: `BD_DEBUG_ROUTING=1 bd show <id>`

## Configuration

### Rig Config (`config.json`)

```json
{
  "type": "rig",
  "name": "myproject",
  "git_url": "https://github.com/...",
  "beads": { "prefix": "mp" }
}
```

### Settings (`settings/config.json`)

```json
{
  "theme": "desert",
  "max_workers": 5,
  "merge_queue": { "enabled": true }
}
```

### Runtime (`.runtime/` - gitignored)

Process state, PIDs, ephemeral data.

## Formula Format

```toml
formula = "name"
type = "workflow"           # workflow | expansion | aspect
version = 1
description = "..."

[vars.feature]
description = "..."
required = true

[[steps]]
id = "step-id"
title = "{{feature}}"
description = "..."
needs = ["other-step"]      # Dependencies
```

**Composition:**

```toml
extends = ["base-formula"]

[compose]
aspects = ["cross-cutting"]

[[compose.expand]]
target = "step-id"
with = "macro-formula"
```

## Molecule Lifecycle

```
Formula (source TOML)  "Ice-9"
    
     bd cook
Protomolecule (frozen template)  Solid
    
     bd mol pour  Mol (persistent)  Liquid  bd squash  Digest
    
     bd mol wisp  Wisp (ephemeral)  Vapor  bd squash  Digest
                                                   bd burn  (gone)
```

**Note**: Wisps are stored in `.beads/` with an ephemeral flag - they're not
persisted to JSONL. They exist only in memory during execution.

## Molecule Commands

**Principle**: `bd` = beads data operations, `gt` = agent operations.

### Beads Operations (bd)

```bash
# Formulas
bd formula list              # Available formulas
bd formula show <name>       # Formula details
bd cook <formula>            # Formula  Proto

# Molecules (data operations)
bd mol list                  # Available protos
bd mol show <id>             # Proto details
bd mol pour <proto>          # Create mol
bd mol wisp <proto>          # Create wisp
bd mol bond <proto> <parent> # Attach to existing mol
bd mol squash <id>           # Condense to digest (explicit ID)
bd mol burn <id>             # Discard wisp (explicit ID)
```

### Agent Operations (gt)

```bash
# Hook management (operates on current agent's hook)
gt hook                    # What's on MY hook
gt mol current               # What should I work on next
gt mol progress <id>         # Execution progress of molecule
gt mol attach <bead> <mol>   # Pin molecule to bead
gt mol detach <bead>         # Unpin molecule from bead
gt mol attach-from-mail <id> # Attach from mail message

# Agent lifecycle (operates on agent's attached molecule)
gt mol burn                  # Burn attached molecule (no ID needed)
gt mol squash                # Squash attached molecule (no ID needed)
gt mol step done <step>      # Complete a molecule step
```

**Key distinction**: `bd mol burn/squash <id>` take explicit molecule IDs.
`gt mol burn/squash` operate on the current agent's attached molecule
(auto-detected from working directory).

## Agent Lifecycle

### Polecat Shutdown

```
1. Complete work steps
2. bd mol squash (create digest)
3. Submit to merge queue
4. gt handoff (request shutdown)
5. Wait for Witness to kill session
6. Witness removes worktree + branch
```

### Session Cycling

```
1. Agent notices context filling
2. gt handoff (sends mail to self)
3. Manager kills session
4. Manager starts new session
5. New session reads handoff mail
```

## Environment Variables

Gas Town sets environment variables for each agent session via `config.AgentEnv()`.
These are set in tmux session environment when agents are spawned.

### Core Variables (All Agents)

| Variable | Purpose | Example |
|----------|---------|---------|
| `GT_ROLE` | Agent role type | `mayor`, `witness`, `polecat`, `crew` |
| `GT_ROOT` | Town root directory | `/home/user/gt` |
| `BD_ACTOR` | Agent identity for attribution | `gastown/polecats/toast` |
| `GIT_AUTHOR_NAME` | Commit attribution (same as BD_ACTOR) | `gastown/polecats/toast` |
| `BEADS_DIR` | Beads database location | `/home/user/gt/gastown/.beads` |

### Rig-Level Variables

| Variable | Purpose | Roles |
|----------|---------|-------|
| `GT_RIG` | Rig name | witness, refinery, polecat, crew |
| `GT_POLECAT` | Polecat worker name | polecat only |
| `GT_CREW` | Crew worker name | crew only |
| `BEADS_AGENT_NAME` | Agent name for beads operations | polecat, crew |
| `BEADS_NO_DAEMON` | Disable beads daemon (isolated context) | polecat, crew |

### Other Variables

| Variable | Purpose |
|----------|---------|
| `GIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL` | Workspace owner email (from git config) |
| `GT_TOWN_ROOT` | Override town root detection (manual use) |
| `CLAUDE_RUNTIME_CONFIG_DIR` | Custom Claude settings directory |

### Environment by Role

| Role | Key Variables |
|------|---------------|
| **Mayor** | `GT_ROLE=mayor`, `BD_ACTOR=mayor` |
| **Deacon** | `GT_ROLE=deacon`, `BD_ACTOR=deacon` |
| **Boot** | `GT_ROLE=boot`, `BD_ACTOR=deacon-boot` |
| **Witness** | `GT_ROLE=witness`, `GT_RIG=<rig>`, `BD_ACTOR=<rig>/witness` |
| **Refinery** | `GT_ROLE=refinery`, `GT_RIG=<rig>`, `BD_ACTOR=<rig>/refinery` |
| **Polecat** | `GT_ROLE=polecat`, `GT_RIG=<rig>`, `GT_POLECAT=<name>`, `BD_ACTOR=<rig>/polecats/<name>` |
| **Crew** | `GT_ROLE=crew`, `GT_RIG=<rig>`, `GT_CREW=<name>`, `BD_ACTOR=<rig>/crew/<name>` |

### Doctor Check

The `gt doctor` command verifies that running tmux sessions have correct
environment variables. Mismatches are reported as warnings:

```
 env-vars: Found 3 env var mismatch(es) across 1 session(s)
    hq-mayor: missing GT_ROOT (expected "/home/user/gt")
```

Fix by restarting sessions: `gt shutdown && gt up`

## Agent Working Directories and Settings

Each agent runs in a specific working directory and has its own Claude settings.
Understanding this hierarchy is essential for proper configuration.

### Working Directories by Role

| Role | Working Directory | Notes |
|------|-------------------|-------|
| **Mayor** | `~/gt/mayor/` | Town-level coordinator, isolated from rigs |
| **Deacon** | `~/gt/deacon/` | Background supervisor daemon |
| **Witness** | `~/gt/<rig>/witness/` | No git clone, monitors polecats only |
| **Refinery** | `~/gt/<rig>/refinery/rig/` | Worktree on main branch |
| **Crew** | `~/gt/<rig>/crew/<name>/rig/` | Persistent human workspace clone |
| **Polecat** | `~/gt/<rig>/polecats/<name>/rig/` | Ephemeral worker worktree |

Note: The per-rig `<rig>/mayor/rig/` directory is NOT a working directoryit's
a git clone that holds the canonical `.beads/` database for that rig.

### Settings File Locations

Claude Code searches for `.claude/settings.json` starting from the working
directory and traversing upward. Settings are placed in **parent directories**
(not inside git clones) so they're found via directory traversal without
polluting source repositories:

```
~/gt/
 mayor/.claude/settings.json          # Mayor settings
 deacon/.claude/settings.json         # Deacon settings
 <rig>/
     witness/.claude/settings.json    # Witness settings (no rig/ subdir)
     refinery/.claude/settings.json   # Found by refinery/rig/ via traversal
     crew/.claude/settings.json       # Shared by all crew/<name>/rig/
     polecats/.claude/settings.json   # Shared by all polecats/<name>/rig/
```

**Why parent directories?** Agents working in git clones (like `refinery/rig/`)
would pollute the source repo if settings were placed there. By putting settings
one level up, Claude finds them via upward traversal, and all workers of the
same type share the same settings.

### CLAUDE.md Locations

Role context is delivered via CLAUDE.md files or ephemeral injection:

| Role | CLAUDE.md Location | Method |
|------|-------------------|--------|
| **Mayor** | `~/gt/mayor/CLAUDE.md` | On disk |
| **Deacon** | (none) | Injected via `gt prime` at SessionStart |
| **Witness** | (none) | Injected via `gt prime` at SessionStart |
| **Refinery** | `<rig>/refinery/rig/CLAUDE.md` | On disk (inside worktree) |
| **Crew** | (none) | Injected via `gt prime` at SessionStart |
| **Polecat** | (none) | Injected via `gt prime` at SessionStart |

Additionally, each rig has `<rig>/mayor/rig/CLAUDE.md` for the per-rig mayor clone
(used for beads operations, not a running agent).

**Why ephemeral injection?** Writing CLAUDE.md into git clones would:
1. Pollute source repos when agents commit/push
2. Leak Gas Town internals into project history
3. Conflict with project-specific CLAUDE.md files

The `gt prime` command runs at SessionStart hook and injects context without
persisting it to disk.

### Sparse Checkout (Source Repo Isolation)

When agents work on source repositories that have their own Claude Code configuration,
Gas Town uses git sparse checkout to exclude all context files:

```bash
# Automatically configured for worktrees - excludes:
# - .claude/       : settings, rules, agents, commands
# - CLAUDE.md      : primary context file
# - CLAUDE.local.md: personal context file
# - .mcp.json      : MCP server configuration
git sparse-checkout set --no-cone '/*' '!/.claude/' '!/CLAUDE.md' '!/CLAUDE.local.md' '!/.mcp.json'
```

This ensures agents use Gas Town's context, not the source repo's instructions.

**Doctor check**: `gt doctor` verifies sparse checkout is configured correctly.
Run `gt doctor --fix` to update legacy configurations missing the newer patterns.

### Settings Inheritance

Claude Code's settings search order (first match wins):

1. `.claude/settings.json` in current working directory
2. `.claude/settings.json` in parent directories (traversing up)
3. `~/.claude/settings.json` (user global settings)

Gas Town places settings at each agent's working directory root, so agents
find their role-specific settings before reaching any parent or global config.

### Settings Templates

Gas Town uses two settings templates based on role type:

| Type | Roles | Key Difference |
|------|-------|----------------|
| **Interactive** | Mayor, Crew | Mail injected on `UserPromptSubmit` hook |
| **Autonomous** | Polecat, Witness, Refinery, Deacon | Mail injected on `SessionStart` hook |

Autonomous agents may start without user input, so they need mail checked
at session start. Interactive agents wait for user prompts.

### Troubleshooting

| Problem | Solution |
|---------|----------|
| Agent using wrong settings | Check `gt doctor`, verify sparse checkout |
| Settings not found | Ensure `.claude/settings.json` exists at role home |
| Source repo settings leaking | Run `gt doctor --fix` to configure sparse checkout |
| Mayor settings affecting polecats | Mayor should run in `mayor/`, not town root |

## CLI Reference

### Town Management

```bash
gt install [path]            # Create town
gt install --git             # With git init
gt doctor                    # Health check
gt doctor --fix              # Auto-repair
```

### Configuration

```bash
# Agent management
gt config agent list [--json]     # List all agents (built-in + custom)
gt config agent get <name>        # Show agent configuration
gt config agent set <name> <cmd>  # Create or update custom agent
gt config agent remove <name>     # Remove custom agent (built-ins protected)

# Default agent
gt config default-agent [name]    # Get or set town default agent
```

**Built-in agents**: `claude`, `gemini`, `codex`, `cursor`, `auggie`, `amp`

**Custom agents**: Define per-town via CLI or JSON:
```bash
gt config agent set claude-glm "claude-glm --model glm-4"
gt config agent set claude "claude-opus"  # Override built-in
gt config default-agent claude-glm       # Set default
```

**Advanced agent config** (`settings/agents.json`):
```json
{
  "version": 1,
  "agents": {
    "opencode": {
      "command": "opencode",
      "args": [],
      "resume_flag": "--session",
      "resume_style": "flag",
      "non_interactive": {
        "subcommand": "run",
        "output_flag": "--format json"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

**Rig-level agents** (`<rig>/settings/config.json`):
```json
{
  "type": "rig-settings",
  "version": 1,
  "agent": "opencode",
  "agents": {
    "opencode": {
      "command": "opencode",
      "args": ["--session"]
    }
  }
}
```

**Agent resolution order**: rig-level  town-level  built-in presets.

For OpenCode autonomous mode, set env var in your shell profile:
```bash
export OPENCODE_PERMISSION='{"*":"allow"}'
```

### Rig Management

```bash
gt rig add <name> <url>
gt rig list
gt rig remove <name>
```

### Convoy Management (Primary Dashboard)

```bash
gt convoy list                          # Dashboard of active convoys
gt convoy status [convoy-id]            # Show progress ( hq-cv-*)
gt convoy create "name" [issues...]     # Create convoy tracking issues
gt convoy create "name" gt-a bd-b --notify mayor/  # With notification
gt convoy list --all                    # Include landed convoys
gt convoy list --status=closed          # Only landed convoys
```

Note: "Swarm" is ephemeral (workers on a convoy's issues). See [Convoys](concepts/convoy.md).

### Work Assignment

```bash
# Standard workflow: convoy first, then sling
gt convoy create "Feature X" gt-abc gt-def
gt sling gt-abc <rig>                    # Assign to polecat
gt sling gt-abc <rig> --agent codex      # Override runtime for this sling/spawn
gt sling <proto> --on gt-def <rig>       # With workflow template

# Quick sling (auto-creates convoy)
gt sling <bead> <rig>                    # Auto-convoy for dashboard visibility
```

Agent overrides:

- `gt start --agent <alias>` overrides the Mayor/Deacon runtime for this launch.
- `gt mayor start|attach|restart --agent <alias>` and `gt deacon start|attach|restart --agent <alias>` do the same.
- `gt start crew <name> --agent <alias>` and `gt crew at <name> --agent <alias>` override the crew worker runtime.

### Communication

```bash
gt mail inbox
gt mail read <id>
gt mail send <addr> -s "Subject" -m "Body"
gt mail send --human -s "..."    # To overseer
```

### Escalation

```bash
gt escalate "topic"              # Default: MEDIUM severity
gt escalate -s CRITICAL "msg"    # Urgent, immediate attention
gt escalate -s HIGH "msg"        # Important blocker
gt escalate -s MEDIUM "msg" -m "Details..."
```

See [escalation.md](design/escalation.md) for full protocol.

### Sessions

```bash
gt handoff                   # Request cycle (context-aware)
gt handoff --shutdown        # Terminate (polecats)
gt session stop <rig>/<agent>
gt peek <agent>              # Check health
gt nudge <agent> "message"   # Send message to agent
gt seance                    # List discoverable predecessor sessions
gt seance --talk <id>        # Talk to predecessor (full context)
gt seance --talk <id> -p "Where is X?"  # One-shot question
```

**Session Discovery**: Each session has a startup nudge that becomes searchable
in Claude's `/resume` picker:

```
[GAS TOWN] recipient <- sender  timestamp  topic[:mol-id]
```

Example: `[GAS TOWN] gastown/crew/gus <- human  2025-12-30T15:42  restart`

**IMPORTANT**: Always use `gt nudge` to send messages to Claude sessions.
Never use raw `tmux send-keys` - it doesn't handle Claude's input correctly.
`gt nudge` uses literal mode + debounce + separate Enter for reliable delivery.

### Emergency

```bash
gt stop --all                # Kill all sessions
gt stop --rig <name>         # Kill rig sessions
```

## Beads Commands (bd)

```bash
bd ready                     # Work with no blockers
bd list --status=open
bd list --status=in_progress
bd show <id>
bd create --title="..." --type=task
bd update <id> --status=in_progress
bd close <id>
bd dep add <child> <parent>  # child depends on parent
bd sync                      # Push/pull changes
```

## Patrol Agents

Deacon, Witness, and Refinery run continuous patrol loops using wisps:

| Agent | Patrol Molecule | Responsibility |
|-------|-----------------|----------------|
| **Deacon** | `mol-deacon-patrol` | Agent lifecycle, plugin execution, health checks |
| **Witness** | `mol-witness-patrol` | Monitor polecats, nudge stuck workers |
| **Refinery** | `mol-refinery-patrol` | Process merge queue, review MRs |

```
1. bd mol wisp mol-<role>-patrol
2. Execute steps (check workers, process queue, run plugins)
3. bd mol squash (or burn if routine)
4. Loop
```

## Plugin Molecules

Plugins are molecules with specific labels:

```json
{
  "id": "mol-security-scan",
  "labels": ["template", "plugin", "witness", "tier:haiku"]
}
```

Patrol molecules bond plugins dynamically:

```bash
bd mol bond mol-security-scan $PATROL_ID --var scope="$SCOPE"
```

## Common Issues

| Problem | Solution |
|---------|----------|
| Agent in wrong directory | Check cwd, `gt doctor` |
| Beads prefix mismatch | Check `bd show` vs rig config |
| Worktree conflicts | Ensure `BEADS_NO_DAEMON=1` for polecats |
| Stuck worker | `gt nudge`, then `gt peek` |
| Dirty git state | Commit or discard, then `gt handoff` |

## Architecture Notes

**Bare repo pattern**: `.repo.git/` is bare (no working dir). Refinery and polecats are worktrees sharing refs. Polecat branches visible to refinery immediately.

**Beads as control plane**: No separate orchestrator. Molecule steps ARE beads issues. State transitions are git commits.

**Nondeterministic idempotence**: Any worker can continue any molecule. Steps are atomic checkpoints in beads.

**Convoy tracking**: Convoys track batched work across rigs. A "swarm" is ephemeral - just the workers currently on a convoy's issues. See [Convoys](concepts/convoy.md) for details.

# The Propulsion Principle

> **If you find something on your hook, YOU RUN IT.**

Gas Town is a steam engine. Agents are pistons. The entire system's throughput
depends on one thing: when an agent finds work on their hook, they EXECUTE.

## Why This Matters

- There is no supervisor polling asking "did you start yet?"
- The hook IS your assignment - it was placed there deliberately
- Every moment you wait is a moment the engine stalls
- Other agents may be blocked waiting on YOUR output

## The Handoff Contract

When you were spawned, work was hooked for you. The system trusts that:

1. You will find it on your hook
2. You will understand what it is (`bd show` / `gt hook`)
3. You will BEGIN IMMEDIATELY

This isn't about being a good worker. This is physics. Steam engines don't
run on politeness - they run on pistons firing. You are the piston.

## Molecule Navigation: Key Enabler

Molecules enable propulsion by providing clear waypoints. You don't need to
memorize steps or wait for instructions - discover them:

### Orientation Commands

```bash
gt hook              # What's on my hook?
bd mol current         # Where am I in the molecule?
bd ready               # What step is next?
bd show <step-id>      # What does this step require?
```

### Before/After: Step Transitions

**The old workflow (friction):**
```bash
# Finish step 3
bd close gt-abc.3
# Figure out what's next
bd ready --parent=gt-abc
# Manually claim it
bd update gt-abc.4 --status=in_progress
# Now finally work on it
```

Three commands. Context switches. Momentum lost.

**The new workflow (propulsion):**
```bash
bd close gt-abc.3 --continue
```

One command. Auto-advance. Momentum preserved.

### The Propulsion Loop

```
1. gt hook                   # What's hooked?
2. bd mol current             # Where am I?
3. Execute step
4. bd close <step> --continue # Close and advance
5. GOTO 2
```

## The Failure Mode We're Preventing

```
Polecat restarts with work on hook
   Polecat announces itself
   Polecat waits for confirmation
   Witness assumes work is progressing
   Nothing happens
   Gas Town stops
```

## Startup Behavior

1. Check hook (`gt hook`)
2. Work hooked  EXECUTE immediately
3. Hook empty  Check mail for attached work
4. Nothing anywhere  ERROR: escalate to Witness

**Note:** "Hooked" means work assigned to you. This triggers autonomous mode
even if no molecule is attached. Don't confuse with "pinned" which is for
permanent reference beads.

## The Capability Ledger

Every completion is recorded. Every handoff is logged. Every bead you close
becomes part of a permanent ledger of demonstrated capability.

- Your work is visible
- Redemption is real (consistent good work builds over time)
- Every completion is evidence that autonomous execution works
- Your CV grows with every completion

This isn't just about the current task. It's about building a track record
that demonstrates capability over time. Execute with care.

1# Convoys
     2
     3Convoys are the primary unit for tracking batched work across rigs.
     4
     5## Quick Start
     6
     7```bash
     8# Create a convoy tracking some issues
     9gt convoy create "Feature X" gt-abc gt-def --notify overseer
    10
    11# Check progress
    12gt convoy status hq-cv-abc
    13
    14# List active convoys (the dashboard)
    15gt convoy list
    16
    17# See all convoys including landed ones
    18gt convoy list --all
    19```
    20
    21## Concept
    22
    23A **convoy** is a persistent tracking unit that monitors related issues across
    24multiple rigs. When you kick off work - even a single issue - a convoy tracks it
    25so you can see when it lands and what was included.
    26
    27```
    28                  Convoy (hq-cv-abc)
    29                         
    30            
    31                                    
    32                                    
    33           
    34        gt-xyz     gt-def     bd-abc  
    35        gastown    gastown     beads  
    36           
    37                                    
    38                                    
    39           
    40         nux       furiosa     amber  
    41       (polecat)  (polecat)  (polecat)
    42           
    43                         
    44                    "the swarm"
    45                    (ephemeral)
    46```
    47
    48## Convoy vs Swarm
    49
    50| Concept | Persistent? | ID | Description |
    51|---------|-------------|-----|-------------|
    52| **Convoy** | Yes | hq-cv-* | Tracking unit. What you create, track, get notified about. |
    53| **Swarm** | No | None | Ephemeral. "The workers currently on this convoy's issues." |
    54
    55When you "kick off a swarm", you're really:
    561. Creating a convoy (the tracking unit)
    572. Assigning polecats to the tracked issues
    583. The "swarm" is just those polecats while they're working
    59
    60When issues close, the convoy lands and notifies you. The swarm dissolves.
    61
    62## Convoy Lifecycle
    63
    64```
    65OPEN (all issues close) LANDED/CLOSED
    66                                
    67  (add more issues)
    68       (auto-reopens)
    69```
    70
    71| State | Description |
    72|-------|-------------|
    73| `open` | Active tracking, work in progress |
    74| `closed` | All tracked issues closed, notification sent |
    75
    76Adding issues to a closed convoy reopens it automatically.
    77
    78## Commands
    79
    80### Create a Convoy
    81
    82```bash
    83# Track multiple issues across rigs
    84gt convoy create "Deploy v2.0" gt-abc bd-xyz --notify gastown/joe
    85
    86# Track a single issue (still creates convoy for dashboard visibility)
    87gt convoy create "Fix auth bug" gt-auth-fix
    88
    89# With default notification (from config)
    90gt convoy create "Feature X" gt-a gt-b gt-c
    91```
    92
    93### Add Issues
    94
    95> **Note**: `gt convoy add` is not yet implemented. Use `bd dep add` directly:
    96
    97```bash
    98# Add issue to existing convoy
    99bd dep add hq-cv-abc gt-new-issue --type=tracks
   100
   101# Adding to closed convoy requires reopening first
   102bd update hq-cv-abc --status=open
   103bd dep add hq-cv-abc gt-followup-fix --type=tracks
   104```
   105
   106### Check Status
   107
   108```bash
   109# Show issues and active workers (the swarm)
   110gt convoy status hq-abc
   111
   112# All active convoys (the dashboard)
   113gt convoy status
   114```
   115
   116Example output:
   117```
   118 hq-cv-abc: Deploy v2.0
   119
   120  Status:    
   121  Progress:  2/4 completed
   122  Created:   2025-12-30T10:15:00-08:00
   123
   124  Tracked Issues:
   125     gt-xyz: Update API endpoint [task]
   126     bd-abc: Fix validation [bug]
   127     bd-ghi: Update docs [task]
   128     gt-jkl: Deploy to prod [task]
   129```
   130
   131### List Convoys (Dashboard)
   132
   133```bash
   134# Active convoys (default) - the primary attention view
   135gt convoy list
   136
   137# All convoys including landed
   138gt convoy list --all
   139
   140# Only landed convoys
   141gt convoy list --status=closed
   142
   143# JSON output
   144gt convoy list --json
   145```
   146
   147Example output:
   148```
   149Convoys
   150
   151   hq-cv-w3nm6: Feature X 
   152   hq-cv-abc12: Bug fixes 
   153
   154Use 'gt convoy status <id>' for detailed view.
   155```
   156
   157## Notifications
   158
   159When a convoy lands (all tracked issues closed), subscribers are notified:
   160
   161```bash
   162# Explicit subscriber
   163gt convoy create "Feature X" gt-abc --notify gastown/joe
   164
   165# Multiple subscribers
   166gt convoy create "Feature X" gt-abc --notify mayor/ --notify --human
   167```
   168
   169Notification content:
   170```
   171 Convoy Landed: Deploy v2.0 (hq-cv-abc)
   172
   173Issues (3):
   174   gt-xyz: Update API endpoint
   175   gt-def: Add validation
   176   bd-abc: Update docs
   177
   178Duration: 2h 15m
   179```
   180
   181## Auto-Convoy on Sling
   182
   183When you sling a single issue without an existing convoy:
   184
   185```bash
   186gt sling bd-xyz beads/amber
   187```
   188
   189This auto-creates a convoy so all work appears in the dashboard:
   1901. Creates convoy: "Work: bd-xyz"
   1912. Tracks the issue
   1923. Assigns the polecat
   193
   194Even "swarm of one" gets convoy visibility.
   195
   196## Cross-Rig Tracking
   197
   198Convoys live in town-level beads (`hq-cv-*` prefix) and can track issues from any rig:
   199
   200```bash
   201# Track issues from multiple rigs
   202gt convoy create "Full-stack feature" \
   203  gt-frontend-abc \
   204  gt-backend-def \
   205  bd-docs-xyz
   206```
   207
   208The `tracks` relation is:
   209- **Non-blocking**: doesn't affect issue workflow
   210- **Additive**: can add issues anytime
   211- **Cross-rig**: convoy in hq-*, issues in gt-*, bd-*, etc.
   212
   213## Convoy vs Rig Status
   214
   215| View | Scope | Shows |
   216|------|-------|-------|
   217| `gt convoy status [id]` | Cross-rig | Issues tracked by convoy + workers |
   218| `gt rig status <rig>` | Single rig | All workers in rig + their convoy membership |
   219
   220Use convoys for "what's the status of this batch of work?"
   221Use rig status for "what's everyone in this rig working on?"
   222
   223## See Also
   224
   225- [Propulsion Principle](propulsion-principle.md) - Worker execution model
   226- [Mail Protocol](../design/mail-protocol.md) - Notification delivery
   227

But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

# Convoys

Convoys are the primary unit for tracking batched work across rigs.

## Quick Start

```bash
# Create a convoy tracking some issues
gt convoy create "Feature X" gt-abc gt-def --notify overseer

# Check progress
gt convoy status hq-cv-abc

# List active convoys (the dashboard)
gt convoy list

# See all convoys including landed ones
gt convoy list --all
```

## Concept

A **convoy** is a persistent tracking unit that monitors related issues across
multiple rigs. When you kick off work - even a single issue - a convoy tracks it
so you can see when it lands and what was included.

```
                  Convoy (hq-cv-abc)
                         
            
                                    
                                    
           
        gt-xyz     gt-def     bd-abc  
        gastown    gastown     beads  
           
                                    
                                    
           
         nux       furiosa     amber  
       (polecat)  (polecat)  (polecat)
           
                         
                    "the swarm"
                    (ephemeral)
```

## Convoy vs Swarm

| Concept | Persistent? | ID | Description |
|---------|-------------|-----|-------------|
| **Convoy** | Yes | hq-cv-* | Tracking unit. What you create, track, get notified about. |
| **Swarm** | No | None | Ephemeral. "The workers currently on this convoy's issues." |

When you "kick off a swarm", you're really:
1. Creating a convoy (the tracking unit)
2. Assigning polecats to the tracked issues
3. The "swarm" is just those polecats while they're working

When issues close, the convoy lands and notifies you. The swarm dissolves.

## Convoy Lifecycle

```
OPEN (all issues close) LANDED/CLOSED
                                
  (add more issues)
       (auto-reopens)
```

| State | Description |
|-------|-------------|
| `open` | Active tracking, work in progress |
| `closed` | All tracked issues closed, notification sent |

Adding issues to a closed convoy reopens it automatically.

## Commands

### Create a Convoy

```bash
# Track multiple issues across rigs
gt convoy create "Deploy v2.0" gt-abc bd-xyz --notify gastown/joe

# Track a single issue (still creates convoy for dashboard visibility)
gt convoy create "Fix auth bug" gt-auth-fix

# With default notification (from config)
gt convoy create "Feature X" gt-a gt-b gt-c
```

### Add Issues

> **Note**: `gt convoy add` is not yet implemented. Use `bd dep add` directly:

```bash
# Add issue to existing convoy
bd dep add hq-cv-abc gt-new-issue --type=tracks

# Adding to closed convoy requires reopening first
bd update hq-cv-abc --status=open
bd dep add hq-cv-abc gt-followup-fix --type=tracks
```

### Check Status

```bash
# Show issues and active workers (the swarm)
gt convoy status hq-abc

# All active convoys (the dashboard)
gt convoy status
```

Example output:
```
 hq-cv-abc: Deploy v2.0

  Status:    
  Progress:  2/4 completed
  Created:   2025-12-30T10:15:00-08:00

  Tracked Issues:
     gt-xyz: Update API endpoint [task]
     bd-abc: Fix validation [bug]
     bd-ghi: Update docs [task]
     gt-jkl: Deploy to prod [task]
```

### List Convoys (Dashboard)

```bash
# Active convoys (default) - the primary attention view
gt convoy list

# All convoys including landed
gt convoy list --all

# Only landed convoys
gt convoy list --status=closed

# JSON output
gt convoy list --json
```

Example output:
```
Convoys

   hq-cv-w3nm6: Feature X 
   hq-cv-abc12: Bug fixes 

Use 'gt convoy status <id>' for detailed view.
```

## Notifications

When a convoy lands (all tracked issues closed), subscribers are notified:

```bash
# Explicit subscriber
gt convoy create "Feature X" gt-abc --notify gastown/joe

# Multiple subscribers
gt convoy create "Feature X" gt-abc --notify mayor/ --notify --human
```

Notification content:
```
 Convoy Landed: Deploy v2.0 (hq-cv-abc)

Issues (3):
   gt-xyz: Update API endpoint
   gt-def: Add validation
   bd-abc: Update docs

Duration: 2h 15m
```

## Auto-Convoy on Sling

When you sling a single issue without an existing convoy:

```bash
gt sling bd-xyz beads/amber
```

This auto-creates a convoy so all work appears in the dashboard:
1. Creates convoy: "Work: bd-xyz"
2. Tracks the issue
3. Assigns the polecat

Even "swarm of one" gets convoy visibility.

## Cross-Rig Tracking

Convoys live in town-level beads (`hq-cv-*` prefix) and can track issues from any rig:

```bash
# Track issues from multiple rigs
gt convoy create "Full-stack feature" \
  gt-frontend-abc \
  gt-backend-def \
  bd-docs-xyz
```

The `tracks` relation is:
- **Non-blocking**: doesn't affect issue workflow
- **Additive**: can add issues anytime
- **Cross-rig**: convoy in hq-*, issues in gt-*, bd-*, etc.

## Convoy vs Rig Status

| View | Scope | Shows |
|------|-------|-------|
| `gt convoy status [id]` | Cross-rig | Issues tracked by convoy + workers |
| `gt rig status <rig>` | Single rig | All workers in rig + their convoy membership |

Use convoys for "what's the status of this batch of work?"
Use rig status for "what's everyone in this rig working on?"

## See Also

- [Propulsion Principle](propulsion-principle.md) - Worker execution model
- [Mail Protocol](../design/mail-protocol.md) - Notification delivery

content.content:
1# Polecat Lifecycle
     2
     3> Understanding the three-layer architecture of polecat workers
     4
     5## Overview
     6
     7Polecats have three distinct lifecycle layers that operate independently. Confusing
     8these layers leads to "heresies" like thinking there are "idle polecats" and
     9misunderstanding when recycling occurs.
    10
    11## The Three Operating States
    12
    13Polecats have exactly three operating states. There is **no idle pool**.
    14
    15| State | Description | How it happens |
    16|-------|-------------|----------------|
    17| **Working** | Actively doing assigned work | Normal operation |
    18| **Stalled** | Session stopped mid-work | Interrupted, crashed, or timed out without being nudged |
    19| **Zombie** | Completed work but failed to die | `gt done` failed during cleanup |
    20
    21**The key distinction:** Zombies completed their work; stalled polecats did not.
    22
    23- **Stalled** = supposed to be working, but stopped. The polecat was interrupted or
    24  crashed and was never nudged back to life. Work is incomplete.
    25- **Zombie** = finished work, tried to exit via `gt done`, but cleanup failed. The
    26  session should have shut down but didn't. Work is complete, just stuck in limbo.
    27
    28There is no "idle" state. Polecats don't wait around between tasks. When work is
    29done, `gt done` shuts down the session. If you see a non-working polecat, something
    30is broken.
    31
    32## The Self-Cleaning Polecat Model
    33
    34**Polecats are responsible for their own cleanup.** When a polecat completes its
    35work unit, it:
    36
    371. Signals completion via `gt done`
    382. Exits its session immediately (no idle waiting)
    393. Requests its own nuke (self-delete)
    40
    41This removes dependency on the Witness/Deacon for cleanup and ensures polecats
    42never sit idle. The simple model: **sandbox dies with session**.
    43
    44### Why Self-Cleaning?
    45
    46- **No idle polecats** - There's no state where a polecat exists without work
    47- **Reduced watchdog overhead** - Deacon patrols for stalled/zombie polecats, not idle ones
    48- **Faster turnover** - Resources freed immediately on completion
    49- **Simpler mental model** - Done means gone
    50
    51### What About Pending Merges?
    52
    53The Refinery owns the merge queue. Once `gt done` submits work:
    54- The branch is pushed to origin
    55- Work exists in the MQ, not in the polecat
    56- If rebase fails, Refinery re-implements on new baseline (fresh polecat)
    57- The original polecat is already gone - no sending work "back"
    58
    59## The Three Layers
    60
    61| Layer | Component | Lifecycle | Persistence |
    62|-------|-----------|-----------|-------------|
    63| **Session** | Claude (tmux pane) | Ephemeral | Cycles per step/handoff |
    64| **Sandbox** | Git worktree | Persistent | Until nuke |
    65| **Slot** | Name from pool | Persistent | Until nuke |
    66
    67### Session Layer
    68
    69The Claude session is **ephemeral**. It cycles frequently:
    70
    71- After each molecule step (via `gt handoff`)
    72- On context compaction
    73- On crash/timeout
    74- After extended work periods
    75
    76**Key insight:** Session cycling is **normal operation**, not failure. The polecat
    77continues workingonly the Claude context refreshes.
    78
    79```
    80Session 1: Steps 1-2  handoff
    81Session 2: Steps 3-4  handoff
    82Session 3: Step 5  gt done
    83```
    84
    85All three sessions are the **same polecat**. The sandbox and slot persist throughout.
    86
    87### Sandbox Layer
    88
    89The sandbox is the **git worktree**the polecat's working directory:
    90
    91```
    92~/gt/gastown/polecats/Toast/
    93```
    94
    95This worktree:
    96- Exists from `gt sling` until `gt polecat nuke`
    97- Survives all session cycles
    98- Contains uncommitted work, staged changes, branch state
    99- Is independent of other polecat sandboxes
   100
   101The Witness never destroys sandboxes mid-work. Only `nuke` removes them.
   102
   103### Slot Layer
   104
   105The slot is the **name allocation** from the polecat pool:
   106
   107```bash
   108# Pool: [Toast, Shadow, Copper, Ash, Storm...]
   109# Toast is allocated to work gt-abc
   110```
   111
   112The slot:
   113- Determines the sandbox path (`polecats/Toast/`)
   114- Maps to a tmux session (`gt-gastown-Toast`)
   115- Appears in attribution (`gastown/polecats/Toast`)
   116- Is released only on nuke
   117
   118## Correct Lifecycle
   119
   120```
   121
   122                        gt sling                             
   123   Allocate slot from pool (Toast)                         
   124   Create sandbox (worktree on new branch)                 
   125   Start session (Claude in tmux)                          
   126   Hook molecule to polecat                                
   127
   128                              
   129                              
   130
   131                     Work Happens                            
   132                                                             
   133  Session cycles happen here:                               
   134  - gt handoff between steps                                
   135  - Compaction triggers respawn                             
   136  - Crash  Witness respawns                                
   137                                                             
   138  Sandbox persists through ALL session cycles               
   139
   140                              
   141                              
   142
   143                  gt done (self-cleaning)                    
   144   Push branch to origin                                   
   145   Submit work to merge queue (MR bead)                    
   146   Request self-nuke (sandbox + session cleanup)           
   147   Exit immediately                                        
   148                                                             
   149  Work now lives in MQ, not in polecat.                     
   150  Polecat is GONE. No idle state.                           
   151
   152                              
   153                              
   154
   155                   Refinery: merge queue                     
   156   Rebase and merge to main                                
   157   Close the issue                                         
   158   If conflict: spawn FRESH polecat to re-implement        
   159    (never send work back to original polecat - it's gone)  
   160
   161```
   162
   163## What "Recycle" Means
   164
   165**Session cycling**: Normal. Claude restarts, sandbox stays, slot stays.
   166
   167```bash
   168gt handoff  # Session cycles, polecat continues
   169```
   170
   171**Sandbox recreation**: Repair only. Should be rare.
   172
   173```bash
   174gt polecat repair Toast  # Emergency: recreate corrupted worktree
   175```
   176
   177Session cycling happens constantly. Sandbox recreation should almost never happen
   178during normal operation.
   179
   180## Anti-Patterns
   181
   182### "Idle" Polecats (They Don't Exist)
   183
   184**Myth:** Polecats wait between tasks in an idle pool.
   185
   186**Reality:** There is no idle state. Polecats don't exist without work:
   1871. Work assigned  polecat spawned
   1882. Work done  `gt done`  session exits  polecat nuked
   1893. There is no step 3 where they wait around
   190
   191If you see a non-working polecat, it's in a **failure state**:
   192
   193| What you see | What it is | What went wrong |
   194|--------------|------------|-----------------|
   195| Session exists but not working | **Stalled** | Interrupted/crashed, never nudged |
   196| Session done but didn't exit | **Zombie** | `gt done` failed during cleanup |
   197
   198Don't call these "idle" - that implies they're waiting for work. They're not.
   199A stalled polecat is *supposed* to be working. A zombie is *supposed* to be dead.
   200
   201### Manual State Transitions
   202
   203**Anti-pattern:**
   204```bash
   205gt polecat done Toast    # DON'T: external state manipulation
   206gt polecat reset Toast   # DON'T: manual lifecycle control
   207```
   208
   209**Correct:**
   210```bash
   211# Polecat signals its own completion:
   212gt done  # (from inside the polecat session)
   213
   214# Only Witness nukes polecats:
   215gt polecat nuke Toast  # (from Witness, after verification)
   216```
   217
   218Polecats manage their own session lifecycle. The Witness manages sandbox lifecycle.
   219External manipulation bypasses verification.
   220
   221### Sandboxes Without Work (Stalled Polecats)
   222
   223**Anti-pattern:** A sandbox exists but no molecule is hooked, or the session isn't running.
   224
   225This is a **stalled** polecat. It means:
   226- The session crashed and wasn't nudged back to life
   227- The hook was lost during a crash
   228- State corruption occurred
   229
   230This is NOT an "idle" polecat waiting for work. It's stalled - supposed to be
   231working but stopped unexpectedly.
   232
   233**Recovery:**
   234```bash
   235# From Witness:
   236gt polecat nuke Toast        # Clean up the stalled polecat
   237gt sling gt-abc gastown      # Respawn with fresh polecat
   238```
   239
   240### Confusing Session with Sandbox
   241
   242**Anti-pattern:** Thinking session restart = losing work.
   243
   244```bash
   245# Session ends (handoff, crash, compaction)
   246# Work is NOT lost because:
   247# - Git commits persist in sandbox
   248# - Staged changes persist in sandbox
   249# - Molecule state persists in beads
   250# - Hook persists across sessions
   251```
   252
   253The new session picks up where the old one left off via `gt prime`.
   254
   255## Session Lifecycle Details
   256
   257Sessions cycle for these reasons:
   258
   259| Trigger | Action | Result |
   260|---------|--------|--------|
   261| `gt handoff` | Voluntary | Clean cycle to fresh context |
   262| Context compaction | Automatic | Forced by Claude Code |
   263| Crash/timeout | Failure | Witness respawns |
   264| `gt done` | Completion | Session exits, Witness takes over |
   265
   266All except `gt done` result in continued work. Only `gt done` signals completion.
   267
   268## Witness Responsibilities
   269
   270The Witness monitors polecats but does NOT:
   271- Force session cycles (polecats self-manage via handoff)
   272- Interrupt mid-step (unless truly stuck)
   273- Nuke polecats (polecats self-nuke via `gt done`)
   274
   275The Witness DOES:
   276- Detect and nudge stalled polecats (sessions that stopped unexpectedly)
   277- Clean up zombie polecats (sessions where `gt done` failed)
   278- Respawn crashed sessions
   279- Handle escalations from stuck polecats (polecats that explicitly asked for help)
   280
   281## Polecat Identity
   282
   283**Key insight:** Polecat *identity* is long-lived; only sessions and sandboxes are ephemeral.
   284
   285In the HOP model, every entity has a chain (CV) that tracks:
   286- What work they've done
   287- Success/failure rates
   288- Skills demonstrated
   289- Quality metrics
   290
   291The polecat *name* (Toast, Shadow, etc.) is a slot from a pool - truly ephemeral.
   292But the *agent identity* that executes as that polecat accumulates a work history.
   293
   294```
   295POLECAT IDENTITY (persistent)     SESSION (ephemeral)     SANDBOX (ephemeral)
   296 CV chain                       Claude instance      Git worktree
   297 Work history                   Context window       Branch
   298 Skills demonstrated            Dies on handoff      Dies on gt done
   299 Credit for work                   or gt done
   300```
   301
   302This distinction matters for:
   303- **Attribution** - Who gets credit for the work?
   304- **Skill routing** - Which agent is best for this task?
   305- **Cost accounting** - Who pays for inference?
   306- **Federation** - Agents having their own chains in a distributed world
   307
   308## Related Documentation
   309
   310- [Overview](../overview.md) - Role taxonomy and architecture
   311- [Molecules](molecules.md) - Molecule execution and polecat workflow
   312- [Propulsion Principle](propulsion-principle.md) - Why work triggers immediate execution
